html.p: Dubh.Org is a web server which is mostly dedicated to the development and support of several open source projects that are hosted on this site.

The server is maintained by Brian Duff. My surname, which has some unfortunate meanings in Northern English slang, as well as being the drink particularly favoured by Homer Simpson & chums is actually derived from the Gaelic Dubh, meaning black. It seemed like a pretty cool name for a web site and no-one else was using it, so I grabbed as many domains involving dubh as possible...
This site is a highly evolved version of my homepage, which has been around on the web since about 1994.

Dubh.Org runs on a Cobalt RAQ3 dedicated server running Linux. It has about 64Mb of memory and a pretty large hard disk. I'm actually renting the server from UK2NET.com, whom I heartily recommend if, like me, you want to use up to date technologies like servlets and xml, but your ISP doesn't allow this kind of thing on their web servers.
I mostly develop the site on my Dell Inspiron 7500 laptop at home. Again, I'd recommend Dell to anyone, my experiences with the laptop have been nothing but joyous (yes, I'm a sad git).

Evil Grin... As much as humanly possible, this site is written using XML. I'm using Apache Cocoon as a web development framework, which allows me write content in XML which is rendered to HTML using XML Transformations (XSLT).
Cocoon uses the Tomcat servlet engine to work. Both these technologies are written in Java, which is very quickly becoming the language for server side development.

I'm also making use of the XSP technology that comes as part of Cocoon. This works a bit like ASP or JSP, allowing you to embed server logic in your HTML code. However, XSP is completely XML based, and results in much cleaner code as a result.

All of this may seem like overkill, but it's not. Honest. These technologies allow you to separate content from presentation. Anyone who has developed a web page knows how much of a pain it can be to preserve the content and change the appearance or style of a page. I can do this really easily by modifying the transforming stylesheets; the XML files that contain the content of the site don't even have to be modified. Likewise, if I need to add or modify content, I don't need to plough through large amounts of formatting code to get to the Real Stuff.
I'm hosting a few other sites on this server. I'm happy to do this for people I know who need more space for web pages or want to play with neato technologies on their pages.
Better Bites is the sandwich shop owned by my parents. I wrote a wee web page for them.
Leaping Frogs is a site owned by a mate of mine from University.
